body_html:
Because shapes need to be on the host since shapes guide memory allocation and memory allocation happens on the host and int32s are used for the shape of the randomuniform op.
…
On Fri, Aug 17, 2018 at 3:49 PM Anthony Platanios ***@***.***> wrote: @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> Is there a particular reason why there is an int32 type constraint on the shape input to the RandomUniform op GPU kernels? It's currently forcing some ops on the CPU and due to initialization colocation constraints this propagates to some variables and their updates making training about twice as slow on a machine with a Pascal 1080. Thanks! — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. -- - Alex
body_text:
Because shapes need to be on the host since shapes guide memory allocation
and memory allocation happens on the host and int32s are used for the shape
of the randomuniform op.

 op GPU kernels? It's currently forcing some ops on the CPU and due to
 initialization colocation constraints this propagates to some variables and
 their updates making training about twice as slow on a machine with a

body:
Because shapes need to be on the host since shapes guide memory allocation
and memory allocation happens on the host and int32s are used for the shape
of the randomuniform op.

On Fri, Aug 17, 2018 at 3:49 PM Anthony Platanios <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> Is there a particular reason why
> there is an int32 type constraint on the shape input to the RandomUniform
> op GPU kernels? It's currently forcing some ops on the CPU and due to
> initialization colocation constraints this propagates to some variables and
> their updates making training about twice as slow on a machine with a
> Pascal 1080. Thanks!
>
